data.title: The Best Movies With Dream in the Title
data.meta_description: Over 100 filmgoers have voted on the 100+ films on Best Movies With Dream in the Title. Current Top 3: Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House, Dream Wife, ...
data.text:
Ranked By

664 votes

130 voters

Latest additions: American Dreamer

Most divisive: Requiem for a Dream

Over 100 Ranker voters have come together to rank this list of The Best Movies With Dream in the Title

How many movies with dream in the title can you name? This list ranks the best movies with dream in the name, whether they're documentaries, dramas, horror movies, or any other genre of film. Do you have a favorite movie with dream in the title? Categorizing movies by words in their titles is kind of uncommon, but that's a big part of why this list is so fun to scroll through. There's probably one movie with dream in the title you think of right away, but you might be shocked to see how many others exist as well.

Notable films with dream in the title include Requiem for a Dream, A Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors, and A Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master, although there are many more examples on this list. This poll is interactive, meaning you can vote the dream movies up or down depending on how much you like them.

Cary Grant headlines this delightful comedy about a man who, frustrated with city living, decides to build the perfect home in the country. Co-starring Myrna Loy and Melvyn Douglas, the film is a humorous take on the trials and tribulations of home construction and the pursuit of domestic happiness. The relatable story and charming performances make it a classic worth revisiting.

Released : 1948

Directed by : H. C. Potter

Also ranks # 229 on The All-Time Greatest Comedy Films

Also ranks # 11 on The Best Romantic Comedies of the 1940s

Also ranks # 8 on The Best Comedies Of The 1940s

Cary Grant, Deborah Kerr, Walter Pidgeon

The chemistry between Cary Grant and Deborah Kerr shines in this romantic comedy about an oil executive who enlists the help of a foreign princess to secure a much-needed business contract. But as Grant's character struggles to keep his personal and professional lives separate, chaos ensues. With witty dialogue and skilled performances, it's no wonder this film remains a fan favorite among lovers of classic cinema.

Released : 1953

Directed by : Sidney Sheldon

Directed by Darren Aronofsky, this powerful drama tells the harrowing tale of four individuals who become ensnared by addiction. Ellen Burstyn delivers a career-defining performance as a woman obsessed with losing weight, while Jared Leto, Jennifer Connelly, and Marlon Wayans face their own demons as they spiral downward. Haunting and controversial, the film leaves a lasting impression on viewers as it explores the devastating consequences of addiction.

Released : 2000

Directed by : Darren Aronofsky

Also ranks # 57 on The 200+ Best Psychological Thrillers Of All Time

Also ranks # 1 on The 100+ Grossest Movies Ever

Also ranks # 13 on The Most Utterly Depressing Movies Ever Made

Betty Hutton, John Dehner, Macdonald Carey

A comedy-mystery, this film centers on an aspiring playwright who struggles to distinguish between his vivid dreams and reality. Co-starring Virginia Mayo and Edmond O'Brien, the film adeptly blends humor and suspense as the protagonist attempts to uncover the truth behind his increasingly surreal existence. Darkly funny and engaging, it remains a unique entry in the realm of cinematic mystery.

Released : 1948

Directed by : Mitchell Leisen

This visually stunning film explores the concept of life after death, as deceased doctor Chris Nielsen (played by Robin Williams) attempts to rescue his wife from a self-created hell after her tragic suicide. Featuring groundbreaking special effects that bring the afterlife to life, the movie examines themes of love, sacrifice, and the power of the human spirit. The film's emotional depth and breathtaking visuals have cemented its status as a thought-provoker for years to come.

Released : 1998

Directed by : Vincent Ward

Also ranks # 9 on The Most Utterly Depressing Movies Ever Made

Also ranks # 260 on 'Old' Movies Every Young Person Needs To Watch In Their Lifetime

Also ranks # 441 on The 470+ Best Chick Flicks Ever

In this screwball comedy, a wealthy young woman dreams of becoming an opera singer against the wishes of her pragmatic family. But when she meets a struggling composer, her life takes an unexpected turn. Featuring memorable performances and zany antics, this film is a delightful reminder of the golden age of Hollywood comedy.

Released : 1935

Directed by : John Cromwell
